Award.AwardTitle: III: Student Travel Fellowships for Special Interest Group of Management of Data (SIGMOD) 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to provide a unique opportunity for database students to present their research results, learn cutting edge research, and interact with internationally recognized researchers from both academia and industry at the ACM SIGMOD 2015 Database Conference. As one of the most prestigious conferences in data management research, ACM SIGMOD/PODS has contributed significantly to the advance of all aspects of data management technologies and applications since 1975. Today, ACM SIGMOD is a dynamic and comprehensive program for publication, education, and interaction; and it is a leading international forum for database researchers, practitioners, developers, and users to explore cutting-edge ideas and results and to exchange techniques, tools, and experiences.

This project will provide partial support for students from U.S. institutions, especially female and minority students, to attend and present their research work at ACM SIGMOD 2015 in Melbourne, Australia. Besides meeting with researchers from academia and industry during regular program sessions, in SIGMOD 2015 students will be able to participate in the following interactive activities as partially supported by this project: a new researcher symposium, an undergraduate research poster competition, face-to-face meetings with leading researchers, and a student mentoring workshop. These opportunities will have a long lasting impact on the future career of the participants. The broader impact is to train the future generation of leaders and workforce in the critical field of data management.

Further information concerning this award may be found at the SIGMOD Travel Fellowship web site: http://www.sigmod2015.org/grants3.shtml

POR.DRECONTENT:
The award was used to support the travel of 18 students to ACM SIGMOD 2015 conference that was held in Melbourne, Australia on May 31 - June 4, 2015. Each student was allocated up to \$1,385 for travel reimbursement. In addition, ACM SIGMOD has provided free registration for these students. Meanwhile, several students activities were included for appropriate training of the students. This includes PhD symposium and student programming contest. Below is the list of supported students, ordered alphabetically, along with their affiliation:


1- Dana Aken (Carnegie Mellon University)

2- Oreoluwa Babarinsa (Harvard University)

3- Leilani Battle (MIT)

4- Shumo Chu (Washington University)

5- Zhiting Hu (Carnegie Mellon University)

6- Nick Katsipoulakis (University of Pittsburgh) 

7- Andrea Lottarini (Columbia University)

8- Faisal Nawab (University of California Santa Barbara)

9- Kerim Oktay (University of California Irvine)

10- Adam Perelman (Stanford University)

11- Orestis Polychroniou (Columbia University)

12- Fotios Psallidas (Columbia University)

13- Natali Ruchansky (Boston University)

14- Jingbo Shang (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign)

15- Cory Thoma (University of Pittsburgh)

16- Susan Tu (Stanford University)

17- Prasang Upadhyaya (Washington University)

18- Xiaolan Wang (University of Massachusetts)

 

The award selection committee was chaired by Alexandra Meliou (University of Massachusetts) and Eugene Wu (Columbia University), and included the following five members:

1- Spyros Blanas (Ohio State University)

2- Philippe Cudré-Mauroux (University of Fribourg, Switzerland)

3- Jennie Duggan (Northwestern University)

4- Olga Papaemmanouil (Brandeis University)

5- Daisy Wang (University of Florida)
